Award.AwardTitle: Biomechanics of the Cell Nucleus: The Role of Chromatin and its Connectivity with Nuclear Proteins and the Nuclear Membrane

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to examine how individual nuclear components contribute to the mechanical properties of the cell nucleus using a novel optical-tweezers assay in conjunction with nuclei from the genetically-facile fission yeast, S. pombe. Studies conducted under this award will test how altering the size of the nucleus, the compaction of the genome, the fluidity of the nuclear membrane, and association of chromatin with the nuclear envelope affect nuclear mechanical properties. Lamins, which are key in determining the mechanical properties of mammalian nuclei, but do not occur natively in S. pombe, will be introduced heterologously to dissect their mechanical properties from their roles in mammalian signaling and gene regulation. Fluorescence imaging of specific chromosome locations during force application to the S. pombe LINC complex, which spans the nuclear membrane, will elucidate how force is communicated into the nuclear mechanical network.

If successful, these studies will elucidate how the mechanics of the nucleus emerge from its constituents, and delineate how the mechanical environment, which is essential for the differentiation programs that give rise to specific cell types, is communicated to the nucleus, where cell fate is largely determined. They will also establish S. pombe as a model system in which the mechanical role of lamins can be decoupled from their regulatory functions, thus providing a platform for future studies of lamin mutants that cause such diseases as lipodystrophy, muscular dystrophy, and progeria. Because embryonic stem (ES) cells and yeast express very low levels or no lamins, respectively, these studies will also lead to new insights into how extracellular mechanical cues drive ES cell differentiation. On the educational side, the students involved in these studies will become a new generation of teacher-scientists, who excel at quantitative approaches and possess the biological sophistication to identify and tackle cutting-edge biological problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cells are subject to mechanical stress, both from extracellular sources, such as forces exerted on the skin or sheer flow across the endothelia of the vasculature, and internal sources, such as forces exerted by the cytoskeleton. Such forces are transmitted to the nucleus and mechanisms that allow the nucleus to adapt to and dissipate mechanical stress are necessary for cell survival. Indeed, disruption of the mechanical properties of the nucleus during normal cellular processes can sometimes lead to disease. In addition, it is now clear that a cell’s mechanical environment is a key determinant of the development of the cell and of the tissue in which it resides. It is an essential challenge to the field, therefore, to understand how a cell’s external mechanical environment is communicated to the nucleus, where cell fate is largely determined, and how the mechanical properties of the nucleus are established and contribute to cell fate. This project showed that the density of the connections between the DNA (chromatin) within the nucleus and the nuclear envelope, that separates the nuclear volume from the cytosol, and the character of these connections, are key factors influencing the ability of the nucleus to withstand mechanical forces. The project focused on the role of three inner nuclear membrane (INM) proteins, namely heh1, heh2, and ima1, which independently contribute to tethering the DNA inside the nucleus to the nuclear envelope. Cells lacking these proteins show large fluctuations in nuclear shape, which were captured via video microscopy and then quantified statistically by a careful analysis of the three-dimensional shape of the nucleus. The shapes of nucleii from cells lacking heh1 or heh2 exhibit large fluctuations, that are rarely observed in cells that possess these proteins. Cells lacking Ima1 display a clear, but more modest increase in these fluctuations, compared to cells with a full complement of ima1. In addition, intact nuclei from each of these strains were isolated and mechanically compressed and stretched by an micrometer-sized bead, held and manipulated in an optical trap. These measurements revealed that the strains lacking INM proteins were significantly softer than strains that possess these proteins, consistent with their increased shape fluctuations. These results make it clear the association of chromatin with the nuclear envelope makes an essential contribution to the ability of the nucleus to withstand mechanical forces.
